\begin{abstract}
The Circular Electron Positron Collider (CEPC) is a future Higgs factory proposed by the Chinese high energy physics community.
Using Monte Carlo samples of 5 ab$^{-1}$ at 250 GeV center-of-mass energy, the benchmark luminosity of CEPC Higgs runs, model independent (MI) analyses on Higgsstrahlung ($ZH$) cross section $\sigma_{ZH}$ and Higgs mass $m_{H}$ are performed with $ZH$ events where the $Z$ boson decays into a pair of muons.
The relative precision of $\sigma_{ZH}$ could reach 0.92\% and the $m_{H}$ could be measured to an accuracy of 6.5 MeV.
Using information from Higgs decay final states, the backgrounds could be further reduced, leading to a mass precision of 5.4 MeV.
The impacts of tracker size are investigated and parameterized for these measurements.
Using similar analysis technology, we analyzed the capability of CEPC in measuring the Higgs invisible decay.
Using $ZH$ ($Z\rightarrow \mu^{+}\mu^{-}$) events at 5 ab$^{\rm{-1}}$, the upper limit of invisible decay cross section beyond the standard model (SM) $\sigma^{\rm{BSM}}_{ZH, \emph{H}\rightarrow \rm{inv}}$ can be determined to be 2.0 fb at 95\% confidence level.
\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}

The LHC has been playing an important role in the Higgs physics.
It not only discovered the Higgs boson~\cite{:2012gk,:2012gu,cmshig}, but also indicated that the discovered new particle is highly likely to be the one predicted by the standard model (SM)~\cite{lhcsub1,lhcsub2,lhcsub3,lhcsub4,lhcsub5}.
Comparing to the data set leads to the Higgs discovery, the LHC will acquire much higher integrated luminosity in its Run2 and future operation at higher center of mass energies.
These data will largely enhance our understanding to the Higgs boson~\cite{hllhc}.
On the other hand, as the LHC is a hadron collider, its Higgs measurement precision is limited by huge QCD background, underlying and pile-up events.
At the LHC, only a small fraction of the generated Higgs boson can be identified, the Higgs total width measurement is also limited.

Compared to the LHC, an electron positron collider has very distinguish advantages in the measurements of Higgs boson properties.
First, it is free of QCD backgrounds, almost every Higgs boson can be recorded and reconstructed.
Secondly, the beam energy and polarization of the initial states are precisely known and adjustable.
Most importantly, the electron positron collider provides absolute measurements for Higgs couplings~\cite{ILC,CEPC}.
Therefore, an electron-positron Higgs factory is an essential step in understanding of the nature of Higgs boson.

The Circular Electron Positron Collider (CEPC) is a Higgs factory proposed by the Chinese high energy physics conmunity~\cite{CEPC}.
The CEPC will operate at a center-of-mass energy of 240-250 GeV with an instantaneous luminosity of 2 $\times$ $\rm{10}^{\rm{34}}\ \rm{cm}^{\rm{-2}} \rm{s}^{\rm{-1}}$ at each interaction point.
With two detectors operating over 10 years, CEPC will accumulate 5 ab$^{\rm{-1}}$ of integrated luminosity and 10$^{\rm{6}}$ Higgs boson events.

A series of simulation researches have been performed on the future Higgs factories.
The International Linear Collider (ILC) community explored the Higgs inclusive cross section measurement using full detector simulation. Using an integrated luminosity of 250 fb$^{\rm{-1}}$ at 250 GeV collisions, ILC achieves an accuracy of 2.5\%~\cite{ILC}.
Compared to the ILC, the collision environment of CEPC has been significantly changed.
First, the ILC uses polarized beam (30\% right hand polarized positron beam and 80\% left hand polarized electron beam) while CEPC has no beam polarization.
Thus the cross sections for both signal and backgrounds are changed.
Secondly, the beam spot size of CEPC at the interaction point is much larger than that of ILC~\cite{CEPC}, result in much weak beamstrahlung effect and much narrower beam energy spread.
CEPC also has much higher integrated luminosity at 240-250 GeV collisions.
Therefore, it is necessary to perform full detector simulation analysis with adequate CEPC collision conditions.

The production processes for the SM Higgs boson\cite{ww1,ww2,ww3,ww4,ww5,ww6} at CEPC are $e^{+}e^{-}\rightarrow ZH$ (Higgsstrahlung), $e^{+}e^{-}\rightarrow \nu\bar{\nu}H$ ($WW$ fusion) and $e^{+}e^{-}\rightarrow e^{+}e^{-}H$ ($ZZ$ fusion), as shown in Fig.~\ref{ZH}. The corresponding total and individual production cross sections for the SM Higgs boson of 125 GeV, as functions of center-of-mass energy, are plotted in Fig.~\ref{CrossSections}.
At 250 GeV center-of-mass energy, the Higgs bosons are dominantly produced from $ZH$ process, where the Higgs is produced in association with a $Z$ boson.

The $Z$ boson has a branching ratio of 3.3\% to decay into $\mu^{+}\mu^{-}$.
Muons can be easily identified and their momentum can be precisely measured at CEPC.
By tagging the $ZH, Z\rightarrow\mu^{+}\mu^{-}$ events, the Higgsstrahlung events can be reconstructed with the recoil mass method:

Therefore, the $ZH$ ($Z\rightarrow \mu^{+}\mu^{-}$) events form a clear peak in the $M_{\rm{recoil}}$ distribution at the Higgs boson mass.

In the reoil mass method, the Higgs boson in the $ZH$ event is selected without using its decay information.
By counting the total number of $ZH$ events, the inclusive $ZH$ cross section $\sigma_{ZH}$ and thus the coupling $g_{HZZ}$ can be determined model independently.
The measured $g_{HZZ}$, combined with other event rates measurements, could be used to determine the absolute value of the Higgs boson width and absolute value of couplings between Higgs boson and its decay final states~\cite{CEPC}.
Meanwhile, the Higgs mass $m_{H}$ can be extracted from the peak position.
The $m_{H}$ measurement is also very important since it is the only free parameter in the SM Higgs potential and it determines all Higgs decay branching ratios in the SM.
The Higgs decay information can be used to further suppress potential backgrounds, leading to a better $m_{H}$ precision.

Many new physics models predict a significant branching ratio of invisible decay~\cite{inv3,inv4,inv5,inv6}.
At LHC, the current up limit of Higgs invisible decay branching ratio is about 40\%~\cite{inv1,inv2}, much larger than the value predicted in the SM (${\cal B}{(H\rightarrow \rm{inv})}={\cal B}{(H\rightarrow ZZ\rightarrow \nu\nu\bar{\nu}\bar{\nu})}$=1.06$\times \rm{10}^{\rm{-3}}$). At CEPC, using the recoil mass method, the measurement precision of Higgs to invisible final state can be significantly improved. In this paper, the measurement capability of CEPC on Higgs to invisible is investigated.

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the MC simulation and samples used in the studies. The details of analyses are presented in section 3. This section covers the MI and model dependent (MD) analysis of Higgsstrahlung, and precision investigation of Higgs to invisible. The MI analysis also shows the effects of TPC radius, thus providing important reference for CEPC detector design. The conclusion is summarized in section 4.

\section{Monte Carlo Simulation}

A GEANT4-based full simulation is performed on the CEPC conceptual detector, which is developed from the International Large Detector(ILD)~\cite{ild1,ild2} at the ILC~\cite{ILC}.
With respect to the ILD, the CEPC conceptual detector has a much shorter $L^{*}$ (the distance between the interaction point and QD0, the final focusing magnet) and less thick return Yoke.
A set of generator samples at 250 center-of-mass energy, corresponding to 5 ab$^{\rm{-1}}$ integrated luminosity, is produced by Whizard~\cite{whizard1,whizard2}. It consists of SM Higgs signal and the major SM backgrounds, including all the 2-fermion processes($e^+e^-\rightarrow f\bar{f}$ with ISR correction, where $f\bar{f}$ refers to $e^{+}e^{-}$, $\mu^{+}\mu^{-}$, $\uptau^{+}\uptau^{-}$ and quark pairs) and 4-fermion processes($ZZ$, $WW$, $ZZ$ or $WW$, single $Z$, single $W$).
The interference effects is taken into account in the sample data set.
For example, if the final states consist of two mutually charge conjugated fermion pairs that could decay from both $WW$ and $ZZ$ intermediate state, such as $e^{+}e^{-}\nu_{e}\bar{\nu_{e}}$, this process is classified as ``$ZZ$ or $WW$'' process.


If there are $e^{\pm}$ together with its parter neutrino and an on-shell $W$ boson in the final state, this type is named as ``single $W$''.
In our analysis, ``single $W$'' background vanishes after requiring a pair of muon in the final states.
Similarly, if the final state is an electron-positron pair and a on-shell $Z$ boson, this case is called ``single $Z$''.
More details about the CEPC samples set can be found in reference~\cite{samples}.
The Higgs mass is set to be 125 GeV for the SM Higgs signal.

The Higgs signal sample are fully simulated with Mokka~\cite{Mokka} and reconstructed with ArborPFA~\cite{arbor}.
A 0.16\% beam energy spread has been included in this analysis.



Limited by the computing resources, the SM backgrounds are processed with fast simulation tool, where the differential momentum resolution and detection efficiency for different type of particles are parameterized.
The fast simulation tool is validated by the comparison to full simulation, see Fig.~\ref{fastsimu}.

\subsection{Model independent analysis on $\sigma_{ZH}$ and $m_{H}$ measurement}

In the MI analysis, the event selection is composed of a pre-selection with loose selection criteria and a multivariate analysis (MVA).
In the pre-selection, the selection criteria are listed below.

\begin{enumerate}[(1)]
\item At least one pair of muons with opposite charge are reconstructed. \section{Summary}

The CEPC is expected to play a crucial role in understanding Higgs properties.
In this paper, the measurement precisions of Higgs production cross
section $\sigma_{ZH}$ and mass $m_{H}$ are investigated with full simulated Higgsstrahlung signal at 5 ab$^{\rm{-1}}$ integrated luminosity at 250 center-of-mass energy,
where the Z boson decays to $\mu^{+}\mu^{-}$. In a MI analysis without
tagging Higgs decay, the relative precision of $\sigma_{ZH}$ is determined to be 0.92\% and the accuracy
of $m_{H}$ is 6.5 MeV with recoil mass method. By using information of Higgs decay,
the $m_{H}$ accuracy is improved to 5.4 MeV. The dependence of peformances on TPC radius
are investigated and parameterized. Reducing the TPC radius by 25\%, the precisions of $\sigma_{ZH}$ and $m_{H}$
are changed to 0.93\% and 7.9 MeV respectively.

The $\sigma_{ZH}$ measurement is the core of Higgs program at $e^{+}e^{-}$ collider.
It determines the absolute value of $g_{HZZ}$ and therefore serves as a sensitive probe for new physics beyond the SM.
It is also an essential input for determining the absolute Higgs width and all the couplings between Higgs boson and its decay final states.
In this paper, the absolute value of $g_{HZZ}$ is determined to a relative accuracy of 0.46\% at CEPC.
This accuracy is one order of magnitude better than that at HL-LHC~\cite{hllhc}.
The result is also statistically consistent with that at the other proposed Higgs factories TLEP(FCC-ee)~\cite{TLEP} and ILC\cite{ILC}.
In addition, we explored the the potential of Higgs invisible decay at CEPC.  The upper limit of $\sigma^{\rm{BSM}}_{ZH, \emph{H}\rightarrow \rm{inv}}$
corresponding to the 95\% confidence level is determined to be 2.0 fb.
All above results are incorporated the CEPC-SPPC Preliminary Conceptual Design Report~\cite{CEPC}.
